###Strategy

In order to graph our absolute value function $f$, we need to find its vertex and any other point on the graph.

To find the vertex, we can use the most basic absolute value function $y = |x|$, which is graphed below.  The graph of $f$ is the result of moving this graph up/down or left/right. 

Once we have the vertex of the graph of $f$, we can find any other point by plugging-in some $x$-value into $f(x)$.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3b9b8f4b4dac19e1197e9dd94553d0822f9fe69a.png)

###Finding the vertex of the graph of $f$

Let's find the vertex by observing how we can move from the graph of $y=|x|$ to the graph of $f$. 

First, note that the graph of $y=|x-2|$ is the same as the graph of $y=|x|$  moved $2$ units to the right.   [[☃ explanation 1]]

Therefore, moving the vertex of the graph of $y=|x|$  by $2$ units to the right gives us the vertex of the graph of $y=|x-2|$, which is $(2,0)$. 
[[☃ explanation 2]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e480f54b06a4fba510d0cdee1311dbfce648cac3)

Now note that the graph of $y=|x-2|+2$ is the same as the graph of $y=|x-2|$ moved up by $2$ units. [[☃ explanation 3]]

Therefore, moving the vertex of the graph of $y=|x-2|$ up by $2$ units gives us the vertex of the graph of $y=|x-2|+2$, which is $(2,2)$.
[[☃ explanation 4]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/af42baa5297c5e544d8559c14ae6df02856c7408)

options.explanation: This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x|$ corresponds to the point $(a+2,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x-2|$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ by $2$ units to the right is the same as adding $2$ to its $x$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x+2,y)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x|$ lies at $(0,0)$, moving it $2$ units to the right gives us the point $(0+2,0)=(2,0)$.
This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x-2|$ corresponds to the point $(a,b+2)$ on the graph of $y=|x-2|+2$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ up by $2$ units is the same as adding $2$ to its $y$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x,y+2)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x-2|$ lies at $(2,0)$, moving it up by $2$ units gives us the point $(2,0+2)=(2,2)$.

###Graphing the function

**We've found that the vertex of $f$ is $(2,2)$, and we can check that $(0,4)$ is a point that also lies on its graph.** [[☃ explanation 1]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/30fe64cd6d15266d99bc8f9bc2f85cb39458f822)

options.explanation: Since $f(0)=|0-2|+2=4$, it follows that $(0,4)$ is a point on the graph of $f$.
